repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
#25394 unified the interfaces for setting number and boolean options. However, there is still a separate `set_string_option` function that is used for setting a string option. This PR removes that function and merges it with `set_option`.

Ref: #25672

comment_data.body: I assume this is only the case when buf/win is passed to `nvim_set_option_value`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value
+  for all global-local options, instead of just string global-local options.
+
+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body:
> I assume this is only the case when buf/win is passed to `nvim_set_option_value`?

Nope, it doesn't have anything to do with `nvim_set_option_value()` in particular, it's just a change in behavior regarding how options are set. Previously, this was the behavior for global-local string options, now this is the behavior for all global-local options regardless of type.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value
+  for all global-local options, instead of just string global-local options.
+
+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body: So when we use `nvim_set_option_value` with no scope it'll reset the local values for all buffers/windows?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value
+  for all global-local options, instead of just string global-local options.
+
+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body:
> So when we use `nvim_set_option_value` with no scope it'll reset the local values for all buffers/windows?

No, only the current buffer/window. And it already did that for string options, btw.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value
+  for all global-local options, instead of just string global-local options.
+
+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body: This seems undesirable, at least for the API and should probably be documented. The API should be agnostic to current win/buf.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value
+  for all global-local options, instead of just string global-local options.
+
+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body:
> This seems undesirable, at least for the API and should probably be documented. The API should be agnostic to current win/buf.

Again, this was already the case for string options. The only thing this PR does is make it more consistent so that it also occurs for number and boolean options. I would be fine with documenting this, though.

> The API should be agnostic to current win/buf.

I generally agree, but unfortunately this was not how options were designed to work. If we really want we could probably add some extra code to `nvim_set_option_value` to set the local value for the curbuf/curwin again but I'm not sure if we really want that. I'll defer this to @bfredl as I don't have any strong opinions on this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value
+  for all global-local options, instead of just string global-local options.
+
+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body: Also, using `:set` (or `nvim_set_option_value()`)  without scope implies setting both the local and global values for a global-local option. All this does is add an optimization (for non-trivial types) by removing the local value since it won't be used anyway.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value
+  for all global-local options, instead of just string global-local options.
+
+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body:
> Again, this was already the case for string options. 

I know! I didn't ignore that.

> The only thing this PR does is make it more consistent so that it also occurs for number and boolean options. I would be fine with documenting this, though.

By making it consistent you've had to change behaviour for a certain type of options. You could have just as easily changed how strings work. 

Either way it seems like we may want to change behaviour in the future so need to be weary of flip flopping.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value
+  for all global-local options, instead of just string global-local options.
+
+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body:
> I generally agree, but unfortunately this was not how options were designed to work. If we really want we could probably add some extra code to nvim_set_option_value to set the local value for the curbuf/curwin again but I'm not sure if we really want that. I'll defer this to @bfredl as I don't have any strong opinions on this.

The API can do exactly what we want it to do, and one of the goals of the API is to remove all current win/buf dependency.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,

-  instead of always being strings.

comment_data.body:
> > I generally agree, but unfortunately this was not how options were designed to work. If we really want we could probably add some extra code to nvim_set_option_value to set the local value for the curbuf/curwin again but I'm not sure if we really want that. I'll defer this to @bfredl as I don't have any strong opinions on this.
> 
> The API can do exactly what we want it to do, and one of the goals of the API is to remove all current win/buf dependency.

Should we add extra code for the API, in that case? Again, I don't consider myself an authority when it comes to making API changes like this so I'd like to defer this to someone else if possible, but I can implement whatever is required.

@@ -73,7 +73,12 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
 
 • |OptionSet| autocommand args |v:option_new|, |v:option_old|,
   |v:option_oldlocal|, |v:option_oldglobal| now have the type of the option
-  instead of always being strings.
+  instead of always being strings. |v:option_old| is now the old global value

+• Local value for a global-local number/boolean option is now unset when
+  the option is set (e.g. using |:set| or |nvim_set_option_value()|) without a

comment_data.body: Potentially. I haven't got all the necessary context in my brain atm, just that a design goal of the API is to also pass win/buf when it acts on them and pass 0 for current win/buf. Deviating from that would be unfortunate.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(options): unify `set_option` and `set_string_option`
